description: The Apple Certified Associate certification is an excellent starting point for people working with Apple Mac systems in a networked environment. The certification covers topics like integrating Mac and Windows PCs as well as connecting to numerous network services. This certification course was previously titled Mac Integration Basics.

The certification covers topics like integrating Mac and Windows PCs as well as connecting to numerous network services. This certification course was previously titled Mac Integration Basics.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.596
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.596 --> 00:00:07.460
Hello, and thank you for watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:07.460 --> 00:00:11.390
We're talking with Don Pezet about
Apple Certified Associate, a new series.

4
00:00:11.390 --> 00:00:13.420
Don, tell us about this series.
>> All right, well,

5
00:00:13.420 --> 00:00:16.770
in this series we're gonna be taking
a look at Apple technologies from

6
00:00:16.770 --> 00:00:20.330
the perspective of somebody who
has to work with them everyday.

7
00:00:20.330 --> 00:00:24.940
This is designed as a kind of a first
step in your Apple certification career.

8
00:00:24.940 --> 00:00:26.960
So we cover a lot basics
that are spread across.

9
00:00:26.960 --> 00:00:28.770
How to use our Mac OS environment.

10
00:00:28.770 --> 00:00:30.980
How to support computer
systems running Mac.

11
00:00:30.980 --> 00:00:35.980
And to be thinking about various things
like security initiatives and so on.

12
00:00:35.980 --> 00:00:38.800
As we step through this course
you are gonna see it covers quite

13
00:00:38.800 --> 00:00:39.650
a range of material.

14
00:00:39.650 --> 00:00:42.000
Probably more than what
a regular end use would need.

15
00:00:42.000 --> 00:00:45.080
But it's geared more towards that IT
professional, somebody who is gonna be

16
00:00:45.080 --> 00:00:48.350
working with these systems, and
needs to know the ins and outs a little

17
00:00:48.350 --> 00:00:51.070
better than the regular end user.
>> So you've already touched on this, but

18
00:00:51.070 --> 00:00:53.780
who else is the show targeted towards?
>> All right, so this is

19
00:00:53.780 --> 00:00:58.010
really targeted towards businesses, people
who support Macs, that's kinda what I

20
00:00:58.010 --> 00:01:01.930
mentioned a moment ago but I said
it's a little more than an end user.

21
00:01:01.930 --> 00:01:04.690
Honestly end users can benefit from
a lot of this knowledge as well.

22
00:01:04.690 --> 00:01:08.330
It'll help you better understand how to
use your Mac and some of the features that

23
00:01:08.330 --> 00:01:11.990
are tucked behind the scenes that most
of us don't necessarily think about.

24
00:01:11.990 --> 00:01:15.590
But the reality is this course
it used to have a name,

25
00:01:15.590 --> 00:01:18.030
Apple used to call this
Mac Integration Basics.

26
00:01:18.030 --> 00:01:22.460
And when it was called Mac Integration
Basics, it was focused on teaching you

27
00:01:22.460 --> 00:01:27.100
how to integrate your Mac with
a Microsoft Windows environment.

28
00:01:27.100 --> 00:01:31.190
And so if you work in a business where
you had Mac and Windows machines and

29
00:01:31.190 --> 00:01:34.560
they needed to work together,
this was the course view.

30
00:01:34.560 --> 00:01:35.900
Over the years it's changed a lot.

31
00:01:35.900 --> 00:01:38.880
It is still called Mac Integration Basics
on some pages, but

32
00:01:38.880 --> 00:01:41.650
it's really
the Apple Certified Associate now.

33
00:01:41.650 --> 00:01:46.480
And it's focused on anybody who support
Macs in a business environment or

34
00:01:46.480 --> 00:01:49.500
is using them in any kind of professional
sense to make sure that they are stable,

35
00:01:49.500 --> 00:01:52.060
secure and up and running.
>> Is there a certification

36
00:01:52.060 --> 00:01:53.380
involved in the course?

37
00:01:53.380 --> 00:01:53.940
Absolutely.
So

38
00:01:53.940 --> 00:01:55.380
that's where we get the confusion, right?

39
00:01:55.380 --> 00:01:58.990
Because it used to be Mac Integration
Basics, and it was just a course.

40
00:01:58.990 --> 00:02:02.560
Then they added the certification,
the Apple Certified Associate, or ACA.

41
00:02:02.560 --> 00:02:04.640
And now, well,

42
00:02:04.640 --> 00:02:08.620
there actually used to be more than
one course that could get your ACA.

43
00:02:08.620 --> 00:02:11.140
This is now the only
course that gets your ACA.

44
00:02:11.140 --> 00:02:13.150
>> So they merged the two together.

45
00:02:13.150 --> 00:02:15.000
So it used to be kinda this
optional component but

46
00:02:15.000 --> 00:02:17.100
now it's all stuck together and
it's one and the same.

47
00:02:17.100 --> 00:02:19.710
So when you hear somebody say
Mac integration basics and

48
00:02:19.710 --> 00:02:23.570
you hear somebody say Apple Certified
Associate, those are one and the same.

49
00:02:23.570 --> 00:02:25.030
So what we're gonna learn
here in this series,

50
00:02:25.030 --> 00:02:27.500
we're gonna cover all the exam objectives.

51
00:02:27.500 --> 00:02:30.860
To make sure that you have the knowledge
in your noggin to be able to sit down,

52
00:02:30.860 --> 00:02:33.430
take the exam and get ACA certified.

53
00:02:33.430 --> 00:02:35.950
And I mentioned earlier that's
kind of that first step

54
00:02:35.950 --> 00:02:37.500
in the Apple Certification Program.

55
00:02:37.500 --> 00:02:41.190
Somebody might choose to continue on to
do Apple Certified Support Professional,

56
00:02:41.190 --> 00:02:43.210
somebody may stop right here at ACA.

57
00:02:43.210 --> 00:02:46.930
It's actually a nice cert to be able
to get because it doesn't have a ton of

58
00:02:46.930 --> 00:02:50.030
information behind it, so
it's easy to grasp all the data,

59
00:02:50.030 --> 00:02:52.140
get that certification and
get that thrown in your resume.

60
00:02:52.140 --> 00:02:55.340
And then you can always choose to
move more advanced down the road.

61
00:02:55.340 --> 00:02:57.040
>> So what sort of episodic topics are we

62
00:02:57.040 --> 00:02:58.350
gonna be covering?
>> All right,

63
00:02:58.350 --> 00:03:00.470
we're gonna jump all over the place.

64
00:03:00.470 --> 00:03:04.030
There is still some integration with
Windows that is part of this exam.

65
00:03:04.030 --> 00:03:07.070
And that's actually what we're gonna
start with, directory services.

66
00:03:07.070 --> 00:03:10.800
Connecting a Mac to a Microsoft
active directory environment.

67
00:03:10.800 --> 00:03:13.152
Those are very prevalent out
there in the business world,

68
00:03:13.152 --> 00:03:14.978
almost non existent in the home,
all right.

69
00:03:14.978 --> 00:03:18.090
That's an example of where home users
don't necessarily benefit from this.

70
00:03:18.090 --> 00:03:20.040
But in the business world,
they are everywhere.

71
00:03:20.040 --> 00:03:21.860
So we'll get a chance
to see how that works.

72
00:03:21.860 --> 00:03:23.690
We're gonna take a look at file sharing.

73
00:03:23.690 --> 00:03:27.010
We can share files across the network and
get our Macs talking.

74
00:03:27.010 --> 00:03:30.670
We'll do email, contacts, and
calendar or collaboration software.

75
00:03:30.670 --> 00:03:32.630
So if you're in a business environment,

76
00:03:32.630 --> 00:03:35.470
you likely have some kind
of centralized mail system.

77
00:03:35.470 --> 00:03:37.480
Maybe calendaring, maybe contacts.

78
00:03:37.480 --> 00:03:42.420
We can integrate all of that right
into Mac OS using the mail, calendar,

79
00:03:42.420 --> 00:03:43.280
and contacts apps.

80
00:03:43.280 --> 00:03:45.550
Which are appropriately named for
what they do.

81
00:03:45.550 --> 00:03:46.086
>> [LAUGH]

82
00:03:46.086 --> 00:03:47.498
>> So we'll get a chance to see that.

83
00:03:47.498 --> 00:03:49.435
We're gonna dabble into security and

84
00:03:49.435 --> 00:03:52.660
some of the security features
that are built into Mac OS.

85
00:03:52.660 --> 00:03:54.110
Which are on by default,
some which aren't.

86
00:03:54.110 --> 00:03:57.070
So we'll get the chance to see which
are which and how to work with those.

87
00:03:57.070 --> 00:04:00.680
We'll do printing, because well,
people still print and we need to

88
00:04:00.680 --> 00:04:01.529
>> Do you think it's good?

89
00:04:01.529 --> 00:04:03.523
[LAUGH]
>> Businesses especially,

90
00:04:03.523 --> 00:04:04.950
printing is really important.

91
00:04:04.950 --> 00:04:07.375
We're going to tackle backing up content.

92
00:04:07.375 --> 00:04:08.064
Time Machine.

93
00:04:08.064 --> 00:04:10.400
Time Machine is really easy.

94
00:04:10.400 --> 00:04:12.450
For a home user, it's easy to forget.

95
00:04:12.450 --> 00:04:13.940
For a business user, it's essential.

96
00:04:13.940 --> 00:04:15.860
We need to make sure that
we back up our system.

97
00:04:15.860 --> 00:04:17.840
So we'll see how to back it up,
how to restore,

98
00:04:17.840 --> 00:04:20.000
how to make sure that our data
is there when we need it.

99
00:04:20.000 --> 00:04:22.960
And if we do have a failure,
that we can recover from it.

100
00:04:22.960 --> 00:04:26.130
And the last thing that we're gonna
tackle is kind of a fun one for

101
00:04:26.130 --> 00:04:29.940
me, which is if you're moving from
the Windows world over to Mac OS,

102
00:04:29.940 --> 00:04:33.490
sometimes there's applications
that still require Windows.

103
00:04:33.490 --> 00:04:37.270
Well, we're gonna see how you can run
those Windows applications on your Mac.

104
00:04:37.270 --> 00:04:39.690
We'll see virtualization
software like VMware Fusion.

105
00:04:39.690 --> 00:04:44.530
And we'll take a look at Boot Camp where
you can actually install Microsoft Windows

106
00:04:44.530 --> 00:04:49.010
on your Mac and have it run side-by-side
with MacOS so that when you boot up you

107
00:04:49.010 --> 00:04:53.020
can pick, do I wanna boot up into MacOS or
do I wanna boot up into Microsoft Windows?

108
00:04:53.020 --> 00:04:55.020
And you still have access
to those applications.

109
00:04:55.020 --> 00:04:58.970
Really neat features, and we're gonna see
them all right throughout this series in

110
00:04:58.970 --> 00:05:00.250
Apple Certified Associates.
>> Thank you, Don.

111
00:05:00.250 --> 00:05:03.540
So if Apple Certified Associates sounds
like a course you'd be interested in, and

112
00:05:03.540 --> 00:05:04.880
you should be interested in it,

113
00:05:04.880 --> 00:05:07.670
make sure you see all the episodes
from our course library.

114
00:05:07.670 --> 00:05:09.858
And thank you for watching IT Pro TV.

115
00:05:09.858 --> 00:05:12.771
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don looks at working with directory services in macOS. He explains what a directory service is and the benefits of using a directory service. He then demonstrates joining a Mac client to an Active Directory domain.
episodes.title: Directory Services
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.310 --> 00:00:01.267
Welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:01.267 --> 00:00:03.072
I'm your host, Don Pezet.
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:03.072 --> 00:00:05.127
>> Coming you live from San Francisco,

4
00:00:05.127 --> 00:00:06.650
California.
>> [CROSSTALK]

5
00:00:06.650 --> 00:00:08.414
[MUSIC]

6
00:00:08.414 --> 00:00:13.274
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.
>> Hello, and thank you for

7
00:00:13.274 --> 00:00:16.370
watching ITPro.TV,
helping you learn everywhere you go.

8
00:00:16.370 --> 00:00:17.207
I'm your host, Zach Memos.

9
00:00:17.207 --> 00:00:19.989
As we continue on with
Apple Certified Associates,

10
00:00:19.989 --> 00:00:23.300
we are gonna be doing directory
services in this episode.

11
00:00:23.300 --> 00:00:24.980
So what is directory services all about?

12
00:00:24.980 --> 00:00:27.670
Well, we know a guy who knows everything.

13
00:00:27.670 --> 00:00:30.460
It's [LAUGH] Don Pezet who's
gonna tell us all about

14
00:00:30.460 --> 00:00:32.990
it, aren't you Don?
>> Said these lofty expectations from you

15
00:00:32.990 --> 00:00:34.775
that I have to live up to.
>> Set the bar real high.

16
00:00:34.775 --> 00:00:35.280
[LAUGH]
>> All right.

17
00:00:35.280 --> 00:00:38.220
I don't know about everything, but
I do know about directory services and

18
00:00:38.220 --> 00:00:41.350
that is exactly what we're gonna be
talking about here in this episode.

19
00:00:41.350 --> 00:00:45.810
One thing that you've probably encountered
if you work in a business environment

20
00:00:45.810 --> 00:00:48.460
is that managing user accounts
can be a bit of a nightmare,

21
00:00:48.460 --> 00:00:53.220
that every computer maintains
their own set of user accounts.

22
00:00:53.220 --> 00:00:58.220
So, if I create a user account called
Don Pezet on my laptop, and I create

23
00:00:58.220 --> 00:01:01.680
a user account called Don Pezet on Zach's
laptop, now, I can log in on both.

24
00:01:01.680 --> 00:01:05.940
But if I change my password on one,
it's not changed on the other, is it?

25
00:01:05.940 --> 00:01:07.933
I would have to go and
change it there, too.

26
00:01:07.933 --> 00:01:12.480
And if we buy a third computer, I've got
to go and create an account there as well.

27
00:01:12.480 --> 00:01:14.520
Well, at small scale, you can do that.

28
00:01:14.520 --> 00:01:15.200
Like home users.

29
00:01:15.200 --> 00:01:17.020
They do that oftentimes, right?

30
00:01:17.020 --> 00:01:20.990
But at a large scale,
that doesn't work out so well.

31
00:01:20.990 --> 00:01:23.320
If I have a thousand computers and

32
00:01:23.320 --> 00:01:25.860
I wanted Zach to be able to log in to
any of them, I would have to go and

33
00:01:25.860 --> 00:01:31.340
create an account on all 1,000 computers,
and that's crazy talk.

34
00:01:31.340 --> 00:01:34.270
And by the time it's done, Zach will say,
well, I wanna change my password.

35
00:01:34.270 --> 00:01:35.480
And I'll say, absolutely not.

36
00:01:35.480 --> 00:01:36.967
We'd have to go and
change it on 1,000 machines.

37
00:01:36.967 --> 00:01:38.290
It's not gonna happen.

38
00:01:38.290 --> 00:01:41.550
Directory services solved that problem.

39
00:01:41.550 --> 00:01:46.080
Directory services let us have a
centralized database of user accounts, so

40
00:01:46.080 --> 00:01:48.710
you create the user account one time.

41
00:01:48.710 --> 00:01:50.548
You assign a password one time.

42
00:01:50.548 --> 00:01:53.468
If someone wants to change a password,
they change it one time,

43
00:01:53.468 --> 00:01:57.130
and it automatically takes effect across
all the machines in your network.

44
00:01:57.130 --> 00:02:02.720
Whether you have 5 or 5,000 or 50,000,
it all takes effect in one fell swoop.

45
00:02:02.720 --> 00:02:06.040
So directory services are really,
really powerful for

46
00:02:06.040 --> 00:02:10.100
businesses and enterprise,
not for end users.

47
00:02:10.100 --> 00:02:12.370
So a lot of people who watch this show
are people who are coming from an end

48
00:02:12.370 --> 00:02:12.960
user background.

49
00:02:12.960 --> 00:02:13.990
Like hey, I'm a Mac user.

50
00:02:13.990 --> 00:02:15.697
I've used them for 20 years.

51
00:02:15.697 --> 00:02:16.574
I love Mac OS.

52
00:02:16.574 --> 00:02:17.811
I know everything about it.

53
00:02:17.811 --> 00:02:19.484
But if you haven't worked in
an enterprise environment,

54
00:02:19.484 --> 00:02:21.510
you probably haven't dealt
with a directory service.

55
00:02:21.510 --> 00:02:23.570
We're gonna see them right here
in this episode, how they work,

56
00:02:23.570 --> 00:02:27.690
how we get connected to them, and how we
can take advantage of that service and

57
00:02:27.690 --> 00:02:33.100
make it available to our users and really
make our support of Mac OS even better.

58
00:02:33.100 --> 00:02:34.970
>> So Don, you've already touched on it,

59
00:02:34.970 --> 00:02:38.570
but why would we use a directory
service as opposed to local accounts?

60
00:02:38.570 --> 00:02:39.149
>> All right.

61
00:02:39.149 --> 00:02:41.950
So there's kinda two
different arguments here for

62
00:02:41.950 --> 00:02:43.976
why we'd go one way versus another.

63
00:02:43.976 --> 00:02:47.608
On the local accounts side, the main
reason most people use the local accounts

64
00:02:47.608 --> 00:02:49.720
is cuz they're easy, right?
>> Yeah.

65
00:02:49.720 --> 00:02:51.590
>> They don't depend on anything else.

66
00:02:51.590 --> 00:02:56.090
I can take one Mac all by
itself with no network and

67
00:02:56.090 --> 00:02:58.620
create a user account on it, and it works.

68
00:02:58.620 --> 00:02:59.250
Right?
It's there.

69
00:02:59.250 --> 00:03:01.860
It just works, to quote Steve Jobs.

70
00:03:01.860 --> 00:03:03.990
So I use the login and that's that, right?

71
00:03:03.990 --> 00:03:07.130
So for most people,
that's exactly what they want.

72
00:03:07.130 --> 00:03:09.580
If I'm not gonna share my
computer with somebody,

73
00:03:09.580 --> 00:03:11.130
I don't need a bunch of user accounts.

74
00:03:11.130 --> 00:03:14.880
I just need the one right
here on my machine, okay?

75
00:03:14.880 --> 00:03:17.460
Where it starts to break down
is if I have multiple machines.

76
00:03:17.460 --> 00:03:20.820
Well, even there,
Apple has started helping out with their,

77
00:03:20.820 --> 00:03:26.521
what's a kind of a closeted
directory service, which is iCloud.

78
00:03:26.521 --> 00:03:29.340
iCloud and the Apple ID.

79
00:03:29.340 --> 00:03:33.340
When you set up an Apple ID,
that's a centralized username and

80
00:03:33.340 --> 00:03:38.246
password that's stored on Apple servers,
and you can log in to your iPhone,

81
00:03:38.246 --> 00:03:42.414
your iPad, your Mac Book,
your your iMac all with that Apple ID.

82
00:03:42.414 --> 00:03:45.179
One account logging in on all
those different machines,

83
00:03:45.179 --> 00:03:47.031
that's pretty slick stuff, right?

84
00:03:47.031 --> 00:03:48.648
That works out really well.
>> Mm-hm.

85
00:03:48.648 --> 00:03:50.727
>> And that is a directory service.

86
00:03:50.727 --> 00:03:55.370
But, it's a directory service
completely controlled by Apple.

87
00:03:55.370 --> 00:03:58.530
Apple could turn it off tomorrow
if they didn't want it running.

88
00:03:58.530 --> 00:04:01.191
If the US government
gave them a subpoena for

89
00:04:01.191 --> 00:04:04.330
a user's Apple credentials,
they would have to turn them over.

90
00:04:04.330 --> 00:04:09.290
That kind of thing happens when you're
using somebody else's directory service.

91
00:04:09.290 --> 00:04:11.840
So for most companies, that's not okay.

92
00:04:11.840 --> 00:04:13.346
For most companies,

93
00:04:13.346 --> 00:04:18.720
they want to have a centralized
directory service that they control.

94
00:04:18.720 --> 00:04:23.150
And that way, if an employee gets let go,
they have control over that account.

95
00:04:23.150 --> 00:04:24.352
They can disable that account.

96
00:04:24.352 --> 00:04:26.100
Versus if an employee that gets let go and

97
00:04:26.100 --> 00:04:30.610
they're using an Apple ID, that's between
that employee and Apple, not the company.

98
00:04:30.610 --> 00:04:33.170
They are actually starting to roll
out these company managements, but

99
00:04:33.170 --> 00:04:34.420
they're really focusing on schools.

100
00:04:34.420 --> 00:04:37.680
So for enterprises,
there's not a great solution for that yet.

101
00:04:37.680 --> 00:04:39.422
Well, not a great solution from Apple.

102
00:04:39.422 --> 00:04:43.506
The solution is to build up
your own directory service.

103
00:04:43.506 --> 00:04:45.815
And that's what a lot of companies do.

104
00:04:45.815 --> 00:04:47.405
And at a minimum,

105
00:04:47.405 --> 00:04:50.475
a directory service is gonna be
providing a centralized user database.

106
00:04:50.475 --> 00:04:51.445
That's the main thing we care about.

107
00:04:51.445 --> 00:04:53.714
That's the main thing we're gonna
focus on here in this episode.

108
00:04:53.714 --> 00:04:56.925
But directory services oftentimes
go even further than that, and

00:16:16.962 --> 00:16:19.450
>> All right, so by default,

00:16:19.450 --> 00:16:22.300
So remember that public folder that

It says, I made this folder for you.

00:16:25.030 --> 00:16:26.720
It's here, you can use it, right?

00:16:26.720 --> 00:16:28.340
But after that, it doesn't know.

00:16:28.340 --> 00:16:30.420
It doesn't know what
files I wanna share out,

00:16:30.420 --> 00:16:33.470
so it's up to me to go in and

313
00:16:33.470 --> 00:16:36.860
And I did that with a folder

314
00:16:36.860 --> 00:16:39.484
I went in to sharing,
I went into file sharing and

00:16:39.484 --> 00:16:41.790

00:16:41.790 --> 00:16:46.300
So I told it specifically,

317
00:16:46.300 --> 00:16:50.640
But if this is gonna be acting like a file

other drives, I need to come in here and

00:16:54.490 --> 00:16:56.850
When I added that,
I took the easy route and

00:16:56.850 --> 00:16:58.850

00:16:58.850 --> 00:17:01.890
If you're a file server though the odds

322
00:17:01.890 --> 00:17:05.670

have other folders and things, and

323
00:17:05.670 --> 00:17:07.110
weird permissions on it.

324
00:17:07.110 --> 00:17:10.040
So when you come through here and navigate
and you pick that other hard drive and

325
00:17:10.040 --> 00:17:13.630
you add that folder, it's gonna fix
the permissions, get them set up right.

326
00:17:13.630 --> 00:17:18.100
And you'll maintain a permissions list for
each folder that you share out.

327
00:17:18.100 --> 00:17:20.100
But you've got to tell the system that,
and

328
00:17:20.100 --> 00:17:23.080
on these permissions
there's three permissions.

329
00:17:23.080 --> 00:17:25.840
There's no access, in other words,
you can't get at it.

330
00:17:25.840 --> 00:17:29.120
There's read only, you can see what's
in there but you can't change it.

331
00:17:29.120 --> 00:17:31.240
And then lastly there's read and
write, you can get in there and

332
00:17:31.240 --> 00:17:34.090
you change it, modify things,
add things, delete,

333
00:17:34.090 --> 00:17:37.660
do whatever it is you need to and
get that kinda put in place.

334
00:17:37.660 --> 00:17:39.280
But those are the main ones.

335
00:17:39.280 --> 00:17:42.270
There's a couple of special permissions
that you might see from time to time,

336
00:17:42.270 --> 00:17:43.590

00:17:43.590 --> 00:17:47.890

but then not read from it.

00:17:47.890 --> 00:17:49.090
It's a really wierd one, right?

339
00:17:49.090 --> 00:17:51.010
>> Mm-hm.
>> And the example I give is,

00:17:51.010 --> 00:17:53.030

00:17:53.030 --> 00:17:55.942

00:17:55.942 --> 00:17:59.400

00:17:59.400 --> 00:18:02.470

00:18:03.750 --> 00:18:07.991
Basically when I slid that term paper
under the door, I had write permissions,

345
00:18:07.991 --> 00:18:09.459
I was submitting my paper.

346
00:18:09.459 --> 00:18:11.244
But I didn't have read permissions,

347
00:18:11.244 --> 00:18:13.430
I couldn't see it once
it was under that door.

348
00:18:13.430 --> 00:18:15.880
I couldn't see other student's stuff
that they'd slid under the door,

349
00:18:15.880 --> 00:18:16.930
it was gone to me.

350
00:18:16.930 --> 00:18:20.410
You can actually set up a drop
box like that in Mac OS and

351
00:18:20.410 --> 00:18:22.310
people can drop files into it.

352
00:18:22.310 --> 00:18:26.400
And to them it's then gone but to you,
you can see everything that's in there and

353
00:18:26.400 --> 00:18:27.740
access it and get at it.

354
00:18:27.740 --> 00:18:29.870
Kind of a neat thing to do.

355
00:18:29.870 --> 00:18:32.060
But it basically shows up right in there.

356
00:18:32.060 --> 00:18:35.700
Give it your information and
it's available.

357
00:18:35.700 --> 00:18:37.370
That's how we're adding that.

358
00:18:37.370 --> 00:18:42.360
Some protocols though like SFPT,
they relay on SSH and

359
00:18:42.360 --> 00:18:45.860
when they connect up you're getting
a shell this tied your user account.

360
00:18:45.860 --> 00:18:49.060
So it's gonna have whatever access
your user account has access too.

361
00:18:49.060 --> 00:18:49.570
>> That's right.

362
00:18:49.570 --> 00:18:51.900
>> If your user account has
access to the whole hard drive,

363
00:18:51.900 --> 00:18:54.490
then that's what your gonna have
when you connect with SFTP.

364
00:18:54.490 --> 00:18:59.180
This is not controlled by
the file sharing screen.

365
00:18:59.180 --> 00:19:02.350
So that's a difference between the
protocols that you'll bump into from time

366
00:19:02.350 --> 00:19:07.890
to time, is that some protocols have this
wide ranging reach, other protocols don't.

367
00:19:07.890 --> 00:19:10.840
So be aware that each one
behaves a little bit different.

Time Machine becomes super mega important.

00:22:12.010 --> 00:22:14.740

not only can you scrub your files, but

00:22:14.740 --> 00:22:17.580

00:22:17.580 --> 00:22:21.250

accidentally being deleted or being

00:22:25.310 --> 00:22:27.410

Really important to make sure

So that's what it defaults do.

445
00:23:07.990 --> 00:23:10.630
So AFP is more than likely on the way out,

446
00:23:10.630 --> 00:23:13.280

All my passwords are for naught and

A lot of people, especially older Mac

a home environment may have the system set

When I was in my system preferences here,

Well, in macOS Sierra and

In older versions, though, you actually

441
00:20:06.920 --> 00:20:08.207
Which would not be a good thing, right.

00:20:08.207 --> 00:20:09.280

00:20:31.804 --> 00:20:35.920

episodes.description: In this episode, Don finishes his dive into the security features of macOS by looking at FileVault full-disk encryption. He then explores VPNs as protection for data-in-motion. Finally he shows you security options for protecting from malicious applications using Gatekeeper and attacks from the network using the macOS Firewall.

But if you've got a computer

you're worried about it getting stolen, or

lost, there is some extra steps that we
need to go to make sure that we're safe.

30

31
00:01:28.560 --> 00:01:30.560

32

How does it protect our data?

33

>> All right.
So what FileVault is,

I gave it its full name a moment ago,

which is
FileVault Full Disk Encryption,right?

What it does is it encrypts
your entire hard drive.

37
00:01:42.430 --> 00:01:45.400
And the goal there is to say look,
my hard drive.

38
00:01:45.400 --> 00:01:48.800
When I power on my computer,
my data is there, it works great.

39
00:01:49.800 --> 00:01:51.300
Things are fine, right?

40
00:01:51.300 --> 00:01:55.080
And I've got it only I have access to it,

they now have my data.

43
00:02:03.160 --> 00:02:04.160
Maybe I've got a password.

44
00:02:04.160 --> 00:02:05.699
Well, there's ways to bypass a password.

45
00:02:05.699 --> 00:02:08.380

46
00:02:08.380 --> 00:02:12.440
Maybe I don't have a password, maybe
auto logs in and he can get at my data.

47
00:02:12.440 --> 00:02:13.940
That's pretty bad.

48
00:02:13.940 --> 00:02:15.250
That's not a good thing to do.

49
00:02:15.250 --> 00:02:17.860
We talked about that in part three.

50
00:02:17.860 --> 00:02:22.800
But another nice thing that we can do
is we can encrypt all of our data, so

51
00:02:22.800 --> 00:02:26.940
that now, even if they rip
the drive out of your Mac, and

52
00:02:26.940 --> 00:02:30.510
stick it as a secondary hard drive
in some other computer they control,

53
00:02:30.510 --> 00:02:34.470
they still wouldn't be
able to read the data.

54
00:02:34.470 --> 00:02:38.800
Having an encrypted hard drive
means that if somebody steals it,

55
00:02:38.800 --> 00:02:39.530
you don't have to worry.

56
00:02:39.530 --> 00:02:42.270
You don't have to worry about them
getting access to your information,

57
00:02:42.270 --> 00:02:46.530
because they would have to break
a significantly strong encryption key to

58
00:02:46.530 --> 00:02:48.500
be able to get into that disk.

59
00:02:48.500 --> 00:02:53.950
And as of right now, even the NSA, the
CIA, they don't have a means to do that.

60
00:02:53.950 --> 00:02:56.610
And that's where there have been a very
legal battles between them and Apple.

61
00:02:56.610 --> 00:02:59.110
The encryption is very, very strong.

62
00:02:59.110 --> 00:03:01.980
It's using, at a minimum, AES 128
encryption, which if you're not familiar

63
00:03:01.980 --> 00:03:03.787
with encryption standards,
not that big of a deal.

64
00:03:03.787 --> 00:03:05.500
But it's a really strong.

65
00:03:05.500 --> 00:03:07.560
So your data is very safe.

66
00:03:08.710 --> 00:03:10.870
This type of technology's
not unique to Apple.

67
00:03:10.870 --> 00:03:14.140
There's other competitors

68
00:03:14.140 --> 00:03:16.890
or Microsoft has BitLocker for Windows.

69
00:03:16.890 --> 00:03:18.720
They all work on the same idea.

70
00:03:18.720 --> 00:03:21.660
That a private key is generated and
tied to your hardware,

71
00:03:21.660 --> 00:03:24.780
somehow, and then your entire
hard drive gets encrypted, so

72
00:03:24.780 --> 00:03:27.720
no matter where you put your
data on the disk, it's safe.

73
00:03:27.720 --> 00:03:33.250
And then, if somebody tries to get at it,
well, then it's useless to them.

74
00:03:33.250 --> 00:03:34.800
Your data stays safe.

75
00:03:34.800 --> 00:03:37.150
So this is becoming more and
more common on every computer.

76
00:03:37.150 --> 00:03:40.370
If you're coming from the Windows world,
you would know this is BitLocker.

77
00:03:40.370 --> 00:03:42.480
In the Apple, it's called FileVault.

78
00:03:42.480 --> 00:03:43.685
>> Well, that sounds fantastic.

79
00:03:43.685 --> 00:03:45.670
So is it difficult to enable?

80
00:03:45.670 --> 00:03:46.820

81

And that's kind of the big

82
00:03:48.140 --> 00:03:49.990
is some technologies are hard to turn on.

83
00:03:49.990 --> 00:03:54.240
This one is super easy, but

84

85
00:03:58.210 --> 00:03:59.200
it's not turned on.

86
00:03:59.200 --> 00:04:02.190
Now, if you install Mac OS yourself.

87
00:04:02.190 --> 00:04:06.540

88
00:04:06.540 --> 00:04:09.480
If you say no, then it doesn't do it,

89
00:04:09.480 --> 00:04:11.750
But most of us don't install MacOS.

90
00:04:11.750 --> 00:04:13.920
We get it on our Mac

or we deploy some kind of network

in either of those situations,
FileVault is not on by default.

93
00:04:20.850 --> 00:04:22.350
So we've gotta turn it on.

94
00:04:22.350 --> 00:04:25.080
Just a couple of clicks and you're done,

00:04:25.080 --> 00:04:26.090
Let me show you here.

So I've got this Mac, it's a fresh

00:04:35.500 --> 00:04:38.810

00:04:38.810 --> 00:04:41.620

00:04:52.102 --> 00:04:54.280

You might see MacOS extended journaled.

00:04:56.320 --> 00:05:00.445
But it just says APFS,
it doesn't say APFS encrypted or

106
00:05:00.445 --> 00:05:03.260

107
00:05:03.260 --> 00:05:07.960
So it's not encrypted as it stands,

108
00:05:07.960 --> 00:05:14.420

00:05:14.420 --> 00:05:17.600
Inside of security and privacy, you've got
a couple of tabs across the top one which

00:05:17.600 --> 00:05:21.540

00:05:21.540 --> 00:05:24.303
It secures your disk by encrypting

00:05:24.303 --> 00:05:26.250
By the way, it's not turned on.

00:05:26.250 --> 00:05:29.560
FileVault is turned off the disk,
Macintosh HD, right?

114
00:05:29.560 --> 00:05:33.522
It's not on by default,

115

Now in order to that,

00:05:41.330 --> 00:05:43.920

00:05:43.920 --> 00:05:45.650
So we do need to unlock our screen.

over this encrypted tunnel.

351
00:16:58.710 --> 00:17:01.060
So if you had a hotel or a conference,

352
00:17:01.060 --> 00:17:04.620
now your data that's being transmitted
over the network is completely safe.

353
00:17:04.620 --> 00:17:09.030
In the security world, they call this
data at rest and data in motion.

354
00:17:09.030 --> 00:17:10.631
FileVault protects data at rest,

355
00:17:10.631 --> 00:17:14.500
data that's sitting on your hard
drive gets protected by a FileVault.

356
00:17:14.500 --> 00:17:19.855
But once it hits the network, it's now
data in motion, FileVault doesn't do data

357
00:17:19.855 --> 00:17:25.380
in motion, VPN does, VPN protects it
while it's in transit, FileVault doesn't.

358
00:17:26.390 --> 00:17:29.266
VPNs don't protect your data while it's
sitting on the hard drive either, so

359
00:17:29.266 --> 00:17:30.630
they don't do the other way around.

360
00:17:30.630 --> 00:17:33.780
So if we combine these technologies we can
end up in a situation where our data's

361
00:17:33.780 --> 00:17:36.820
encrypted and
secured at every step along the journey.

362
00:17:36.820 --> 00:17:38.670
But you'll have to get with
your network administrators,

363
00:17:38.670 --> 00:17:41.760
there's a lot more involved in
getting that kind of thing setup.

364
00:17:41.760 --> 00:17:46.640
But it isn't there by default, and
it's important to have that expectation,

365
00:17:46.640 --> 00:17:47.950
to understand the limitation.

366
00:17:47.950 --> 00:17:51.900
Of what FileVault and some of these
other systems are even capable of doing

367
00:17:51.900 --> 00:17:54.530
cuz there's only so much they can do.

368
00:17:54.530 --> 00:17:58.090
Because Apple doesn't know your network,
they don't know your data and

369
00:17:58.090 --> 00:18:00.920
some of the things that might
be going on behind the scenes.

370
00:18:00.920 --> 00:18:04.350
>> But you have to have a VPN
concentrator available to you, right?

371
00:18:04.350 --> 00:18:07.280
>> Right, and
it used to be dedicated hardware, so

372
00:18:07.280 --> 00:18:10.670
at your business, they would have
this appliance that you VPN into.

373
00:18:10.670 --> 00:18:14.230
These days, it could just be a server
that are running Mac OS or Linux.

374
00:18:14.230 --> 00:18:19.510
Although Apple, important caveat here,
Apple just killed of the VPN

375
00:18:19.510 --> 00:18:24.960
server in the Mac OS server app about
three weeks ago when this this filmed.

376
00:18:24.960 --> 00:18:26.910
Depending on when you watch this
it could be a year ago now.

377
00:18:26.910 --> 00:18:28.340
>> It was April 2018.

378
00:18:28.340 --> 00:18:32.531
>> Yep, so
with macOS High Sierra 10.13 that was

379
00:18:32.531 --> 00:18:37.510
the first server version that
came out before it had VPN's.

380
00:18:37.510 --> 00:18:42.553
I believe it was the server app 5.5 and
then starting with 5.6 and higher, the VPN

381
00:18:42.553 --> 00:18:47.260
server was gone, so Apple no longer
has a VPN server product of any sort.

382
00:18:47.260 --> 00:18:51.550
So you'll need a product from
somebody else, Microsoft, Cisco,

383
00:18:51.550 --> 00:18:55.710
Juniper, there's a bunch of companies
out there that make VPN concentrators.

384
00:18:55.710 --> 00:18:57.830
It's built into a lot of firewalls so

385
00:18:57.830 --> 00:19:01.490
your firewall hardware might actually
have VPN support built into it, or

386
00:19:01.490 --> 00:19:06.110
you can stand up a Linux server,
it can create a VPN pretty easily.

387
00:19:06.110 --> 00:19:12.800
Or you can install OpenSSL or
even OpenSSH on your own Mac and

388
00:19:12.800 --> 00:19:16.530
build up VPN Tunnels that way, so there's
a number of solutions that are out there.

389
00:19:16.530 --> 00:19:21.620
But Mac OS as of now just has client
software not server software for

390
00:19:21.620 --> 00:19:22.770
dealing with VPNs.

391
00:19:22.770 --> 00:19:26.656
>> Fantastic information, Don well
presented as usual, security features part

392
00:19:26.656 --> 00:19:30.940
4, remember, there's parts 1, 2, and
3, so make sure you see all of them.

393
00:19:30.940 --> 00:19:33.780
Before we move on,
anything else you'd like to say?

394
00:19:33.780 --> 00:19:36.760
>> In these four parts, we've talked
about a number of security features that

395
00:19:36.760 --> 00:19:38.420
are stashed away inside a macOS.

396
00:19:38.420 --> 00:19:41.820
Some are important, some are not,
it's up to you to look at all of them and

397
00:19:41.820 --> 00:19:44.080
figure out which ones you need and
which ones you don't.

398
00:19:44.080 --> 00:19:49.580
Some of them, like the macOS firewall,
I rarely turn that on, I know it's there,

399
00:19:49.580 --> 00:19:52.870
but I don't necessarily need it so
I don't usually turn that one on.

400
00:19:52.870 --> 00:19:55.858
It can cause some problems too, it can
be a little too restrictive sometimes.

401
00:19:55.858 --> 00:19:58.940
So you've gotta evaluate whether or
not you need each of these, and

402
00:19:58.940 --> 00:20:02.010
then if you do need it, figure out how
you want to deploy and configure it.

403
00:20:02.010 --> 00:20:05.610
Everybody's needs are a little different,
so take into account the software you run,

404
00:20:05.610 --> 00:20:08.510
the type of people that you work with,
the networks that you're on.

405
00:20:08.510 --> 00:20:11.260
That's all gonna influence which
features you need to use and

406
00:20:11.260 --> 00:20:12.470
which ones you [INAUDIBLE].

407
00:20:12.470 --> 00:20:14.050
>> Awesome stuff, Don thank you so much.

408
00:20:14.050 --> 00:20:17.630
And now you know, Apple Certified
Associates, a wonderful series Don's put

409
00:20:17.630 --> 00:20:21.460
together for you, make sure you see every
episode, you're gonna be so glad you did.

410
00:20:21.460 --> 00:20:24.640
And guess what, it'll be in the course
library, there's thousands of other videos

411
00:20:24.640 --> 00:20:28.095
there designed to do one thing, help you
go further, check those out as well.

412
00:20:28.095 --> 00:20:32.680
And tell everybody you know about ITProTV,
you know ITProTV is binge worthy.

413
00:20:32.680 --> 00:20:34.230
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

414
00:20:34.230 --> 00:20:35.020
>> And I'm Don Pezet.

415
00:20:35.020 --> 00:20:37.932
>> We will see you again very soon.

416
00:20:37.932 --> 00:20:44.047
[MUSIC]

417
00:20:44.047 --> 00:20:46.410
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explores printing with a Mac running High Sierra. He takes you through all the basics like connecting to a USB printer, a network printer, and wireless printers. Then he looks at printer sharing, setting up an IP printer, and specifying printer features.
episodes.title: Printing
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:01.322
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.322 --> 00:00:08.260
I'm your host, Don Pezet, coming at you
live from San Francisco, California.

3
00:00:08.260 --> 00:00:12.120
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.120 --> 00:00:13.870
>> Hello and thank you for
watching ITProTV,

5
00:00:13.870 --> 00:00:16.880
empowering the world to engaging learning.

6
00:00:16.880 --> 00:00:20.620
I'm your host, Zach Memos, for
this episode of Apple Certified Associate.

7
00:00:20.620 --> 00:00:23.538
This episode, printing, that's right.

8
00:00:23.538 --> 00:00:25.100
We're gonna be talking about printing.

9
00:00:25.100 --> 00:00:28.170
And the person that's gonna be helping us
with that is the one and only Don Pezet.

10
00:00:28.170 --> 00:00:29.370
Don, good to see you, Sir.

11
00:00:29.370 --> 00:00:30.472
>> Hey, glad to be back, Zach.

12
00:00:30.472 --> 00:00:33.140
And yeah, like you said, we're gonna
be tackling printing in this episode.

13
00:00:33.140 --> 00:00:37.260
I know it seems like a kind
of archaic topic to cover and

14
00:00:37.260 --> 00:00:40.120
with all of our technologies that
have changed so much over the years.

15
00:00:40.120 --> 00:00:44.220
When I look at my MacBook,
the keyboard, right?

16
00:00:44.220 --> 00:00:47.040
I've had a keyboard ever since my
first computer that's been there.

17
00:00:47.040 --> 00:00:49.270
But instead of a mouse,
I've got a touch pad.

18
00:00:49.270 --> 00:00:51.270
Instead of a CRT, I've got an LCD.

19
00:00:51.270 --> 00:00:54.767
A screen's changed,
wireless networking, wired networking.

20
00:00:54.767 --> 00:00:58.000
But printing seems to be this one
technology that just won't go away.

21
00:00:58.000 --> 00:00:58.980
Printing and keyboards, right?

22
00:00:58.980 --> 00:01:00.600
Those are the two things we're stuck with.

23
00:01:00.600 --> 00:01:05.130
If you were in a business,
the odds are you need to print documents.

24
00:01:05.130 --> 00:01:07.610
It just happens, we need to sign things.

25
00:01:07.610 --> 00:01:09.040
You can do it digitally in a lot of cases.

26
00:01:09.040 --> 00:01:11.540
Some companies have gone all digital,
but many,

27
00:01:11.540 --> 00:01:15.050
many organizations out there still
rely very heavily on printers.

28
00:01:15.050 --> 00:01:18.820
And if your printer doesn't work,
it creates extremely bad experience for

29
00:01:18.820 --> 00:01:20.040
that end user.

30
00:01:20.040 --> 00:01:23.820
As a home user, we don't care so much,
but in a business, they are important.

31
00:01:23.820 --> 00:01:24.450
So in this episode,

32
00:01:24.450 --> 00:01:27.870
we're gonna talk a little bit about how
printing is managed inside of macOS and

33
00:01:27.870 --> 00:01:30.970
how we get that set up, to make sure that
when we need to use the printer, we can.

34
00:01:30.970 --> 00:01:33.360
That it's there and
it's all functioning inside the macOS.

35
00:01:33.360 --> 00:01:36.680
>> So Don,
how do we add a printer in macOS?

36
00:01:36.680 --> 00:01:39.100
>> Fortunately,
it's gotten a lot easier over the years.

37
00:01:39.100 --> 00:01:42.503
In the past,
as we go way back in the past, right,

38
00:01:42.503 --> 00:01:47.141
you'd get a printer and it had to be
a printer that was made for a Mac.

39
00:01:47.141 --> 00:01:49.311
That a lot of Macs had
a SCSI port on the back so

40
00:01:49.311 --> 00:01:52.790
you had to run a SCSI cable to connect,
a special type of cable.

41
00:01:52.790 --> 00:01:55.778
Eventually, it started doing ones with
parallel ports so you could do that.

42
00:01:55.778 --> 00:01:57.950
And then they started moving through
these different types of ports.

43
00:01:57.950 --> 00:02:00.760
It was super annoying and confusing.

44
00:02:00.760 --> 00:02:05.190
But Apple has made some big moves
inside of the printing world

45
00:02:05.190 --> 00:02:10.240
to make it a lot more standard, and
now we don't really even have to sweat it.

46
00:02:10.240 --> 00:02:14.290
When we go to the store to buy a printer,
I don't even normally bother to even look

47
00:02:14.290 --> 00:02:17.810
and see if it has Apple support or
not because it's all so common.

48
00:02:17.810 --> 00:02:22.140
What really changed here is in the old
days, Apple used different hardware than

49
00:02:22.140 --> 00:02:24.640
everybody else, so
we needed different printers.

50
00:02:24.640 --> 00:02:29.500
But now, Apple uses the same ports,
the same connectors as everybody else,

51
00:02:29.500 --> 00:02:32.820
which is usually gonna be either USB or
network.

52
00:02:32.820 --> 00:02:34.630
With USB, it's just a USB cable.

53
00:02:34.630 --> 00:02:37.990
You get a printer with USB cable,
you plug it in and macOS sees this.

54
00:02:37.990 --> 00:02:39.470
That was one piece of the puzzle.

55
00:02:39.470 --> 00:02:42.350
The other piece of the puzzle
was the software, the driver.

56
00:02:42.350 --> 00:02:47.020
And in the olden days, when somebody
designed a printer, so if you were HP or

57
00:02:47.020 --> 00:02:50.560
Canon, Brother, somebody like that,
if you manufactured a printer,

58
00:02:50.560 --> 00:02:53.520
you had to write a driver to allow
an operating system to talk to it.

59
00:02:53.520 --> 00:02:54.330
>> Yes, you did.

60
00:02:54.330 --> 00:02:57.038
>> And they would definitely
write a Windows driver, right,

61
00:02:57.038 --> 00:02:59.810
because 90% of businesses run
Windows on their desktop.

62
00:02:59.810 --> 00:03:02.060
So we definitely want a Windows driver.

63
00:03:02.060 --> 00:03:04.430
And then we look at it and
say, well, it's Macs,

64
00:03:04.430 --> 00:03:08.540
they're less than 5% of the market share,
maybe we'll skip that, right?

65
00:03:08.540 --> 00:03:09.679
Not all of them.
Some of them are like HP.

66
00:03:09.679 --> 00:03:13.948
HP was famous for really working closely
with Apple so that macOS had tons of

67
00:03:13.948 --> 00:03:18.165
drivers for HP printers built right in,
and they still do today, right?

68
00:03:18.165 --> 00:03:21.871
But the main problem was most companies
weren't willing to write a second version

69
00:03:21.871 --> 00:03:24.810
of their driver unless
there was a bigger gain.

70
00:03:24.810 --> 00:03:27.470
And so what Apple did with OS X,

71
00:03:27.470 --> 00:03:32.750
is they released a system called CUPS,
with the common Unix printing system.

72
00:03:32.750 --> 00:03:37.153
Unix is that operating system that's
running under the hood, underneath OS X or

73
00:03:37.153 --> 00:03:40.060
macOS, right, so it's running BSD Unix.

74
00:03:40.060 --> 00:03:44.580
Well, the Unix mentality is carried
over to a lot of operating systems like

75
00:03:44.580 --> 00:03:49.410
FreeBSD and OpenBSD Linux,
all the big Linux distributions.

76
00:03:49.410 --> 00:03:54.540
They all are able to share this
CUPS environment that Apple wrote.

77
00:03:54.540 --> 00:03:57.266
Apple wrote it and they gave away for
free to all these other companies,

78
00:03:57.266 --> 00:04:00.093
all these other organizations said hey,
use this in your distribution.

79
00:04:00.093 --> 00:04:03.701
If we all use it,
now vendors can write one driver and

80
00:04:03.701 --> 00:04:08.120
it works on all these different
systems and it's a big win.

81
00:04:08.120 --> 00:04:10.723
Now they're not looking at us and
saying well, Apple's only 5%.

82
00:04:10.723 --> 00:04:15.820
They're saying if I combine Apple
with Linux with BSD with Android

83
00:04:15.820 --> 00:04:21.940
with all these other platforms,
now it's 10, 15, 20% of the market.

84
00:04:21.940 --> 00:04:24.250
Now it's worthwhile to write that driver.

85
00:04:24.250 --> 00:04:28.830
And so most vendors do write drivers now
that directly support the CUPS environment

86
00:04:28.830 --> 00:04:31.460
which directly supports macOS.

87
00:04:31.460 --> 00:04:36.580
So the hardware is standard,
the drivers are a lot more common.

88
00:04:36.580 --> 00:04:39.010
And that means when it comes
to hooking up a printer,

89
00:04:39.010 --> 00:04:42.605
usually we plug in a USB cable and
we're done.

90
00:04:42.605 --> 00:04:46.730
macOS automatically finds the printer,
automatically sets it up, and

91
00:04:46.730 --> 00:04:47.390
we're in business.

92
00:04:47.390 --> 00:04:48.930
It's all that it takes.

93
00:04:48.930 --> 00:04:50.330
We're connected.

94
00:04:50.330 --> 00:04:53.490
But that's if we're just using
the printer on one computer.

95
00:04:53.490 --> 00:04:55.122
I'm plugging into my computer.

96
00:04:55.122 --> 00:04:56.952
But we don't normally
do that anymore either.

97
00:04:56.952 --> 00:04:59.850
We wanna share the printer
between more than one computer.

98
00:04:59.850 --> 00:05:02.150
In that case,
we're gonna have a network, right?

99
00:05:02.150 --> 00:05:04.000
The printer might have
a network jack that's on it.

100
00:05:04.000 --> 00:05:07.760
You plug in a physical network cable or
it connects to a wireless network and

101
00:05:07.760 --> 00:05:08.870
now it's on that.

102
00:05:08.870 --> 00:05:11.550
So in those cases, I have to go to my Mac,

103
00:05:11.550 --> 00:05:13.800
and it's not gonna
automatically see the printer.

104
00:05:13.800 --> 00:05:17.490
Because I'm not plugging in a cable,
I have to tell it, I have to go into my

105
00:05:17.490 --> 00:05:21.350
configuration and tell it, hey, there's
a printer out there on the network.

106
00:05:21.350 --> 00:05:24.690
And it can find it,
connect to it and get that put on.

107
00:05:24.690 --> 00:05:26.900
So for example here,
if I show you on this machine.

108
00:05:26.900 --> 00:05:31.010
I'm on a, this is a fresh install
of high Sierra and if I go into my

109
00:05:31.010 --> 00:05:37.690
System Preferences and I go into Printers
and Scanners, I'll see my printers.

110
00:05:37.690 --> 00:05:38.595
I don't have any.

111
00:05:38.595 --> 00:05:40.335
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's a new system.

112
00:05:40.335 --> 00:05:42.436
>> That's right.
>> And I haven't plugged in a printer with

113
00:05:42.436 --> 00:05:45.070
a USB cable so it's not seeing that.

114
00:05:45.070 --> 00:05:50.550
But if I hit the little plus sign,
it's finding nearby printers.

115
00:05:50.550 --> 00:05:52.370
It's looking at the network.

116
00:05:52.370 --> 00:05:55.040
And it's seeing, look,
there's an HP Color Laser Jet M553.

117
00:05:56.300 --> 00:05:57.840
There is ITProTV Office.

118
00:05:57.840 --> 00:05:59.690
That's the printer that I use normally.

119
00:05:59.690 --> 00:06:02.417
And then Tim's Office, ooh,
there's a printer in Tim's office.

120
00:06:02.417 --> 00:06:03.670
So we can have some of that.

121
00:06:03.670 --> 00:06:06.190
So it's finding these
printers on the network.

122
00:06:06.190 --> 00:06:07.260
It's looking out there.

123
00:06:07.260 --> 00:06:07.900
It's finding them.

124
00:06:07.900 --> 00:06:09.010
It sees them.

125
00:06:09.010 --> 00:06:12.425
And if I wanna add one in like that
printer that I normally use is M506.

126
00:06:12.425 --> 00:06:13.910
I can click on it.

127
00:06:13.910 --> 00:06:15.700
And now it's talking to that printer.

128
00:06:15.700 --> 00:06:17.839
It's adding it in, and I'm done.

129
00:06:17.839 --> 00:06:19.610
I didn't have to go and download a driver.

130
00:06:19.610 --> 00:06:22.660
I didn't have to jump through hoops or
anything.

131
00:06:22.660 --> 00:06:27.720
It already knew the printer was there,
recognized what it was and

132
00:06:27.720 --> 00:06:29.040
got it added in.

133
00:06:29.040 --> 00:06:31.117
So now, we're in business.

134
00:06:31.117 --> 00:06:34.850
>> Are wired and
wireless printers configured the same way?

135
00:06:34.850 --> 00:06:38.052
>> Yeah, well, I mentioned we could
be plugging in a physical cable or

136
00:06:38.052 --> 00:06:39.756
we could connect via the wireless.

137
00:06:39.756 --> 00:06:42.830
A network connection is a network
connection to these printers.

138
00:06:42.830 --> 00:06:45.926
So when I look at this one,
I connected to it over the network.

139
00:06:45.926 --> 00:06:47.190
I actually don't know.

140
00:06:47.190 --> 00:06:48.840
Is it wired, or is it wireless?

141
00:06:48.840 --> 00:06:50.360
I'm not sure.

142
00:06:50.360 --> 00:06:51.551
Legitimately, I'm not sure.

143
00:06:51.551 --> 00:06:52.244
I'd have to go in.

144
00:06:52.244 --> 00:06:52.839
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

145
00:06:52.839 --> 00:06:54.130
>> And take a look at the front

146
00:06:54.130 --> 00:06:55.017
of that printer.

147
00:06:55.017 --> 00:06:56.447
This is a business printer, so

148
00:06:56.447 --> 00:07:00.410
the odds are it's got a physical network
cable plugged into the back of it, right?

149
00:07:00.410 --> 00:07:01.460
>> Right.
>> On a home printer,

150
00:07:01.460 --> 00:07:04.400
like the printer I have at my own house,
that one is wireless.

151
00:07:04.400 --> 00:07:08.030
But when we communicate,
we're using network protocols and

152
00:07:08.030 --> 00:07:13.170
we sort of saw that when I hit plus and
it's showing these printers, right?

153
00:07:13.170 --> 00:07:17.140
It's finding them using different
protocols, and it might find them

154
00:07:17.140 --> 00:07:20.970
using Bonjour, which is a discovery

you this would be the same as if we

hoc wireless network between your systems,

00:01:05.345 --> 00:01:06.367
How it does it's job.

26

What it does and how it gives us a super

So, the next time you hear somebody say,
they lost their information and

It was so easy,

So that's what we're gonna see,

31
00:01:22.440 --> 00:01:24.730
>> So Don, first of all,
how does Time Machine work?

32
00:01:24.730 --> 00:01:26.950
>> All right so
it works on pretty neat system.

33
00:01:26.950 --> 00:01:30.338
So the idea with Time Machine
is that you have a Mac and

34
00:01:30.338 --> 00:01:32.650
cuz it's Apple software, right?

35
00:01:32.650 --> 00:01:36.324
So it's gonna be a Mac,
maybe it's an iMac, a Mac Pro,

36
00:01:36.324 --> 00:01:41.540
Mac Mini, Macbook, Airbook,
whatever or Macbook Air, names, right?

37
00:01:41.540 --> 00:01:43.220
And you want to back it up.

38
00:01:43.220 --> 00:01:45.370
All right, you need to keep
an extra copy of the data.

39
00:01:45.370 --> 00:01:50.240
Well most Macs only have one hard
drive and don't have room for more.

40
00:01:50.240 --> 00:01:53.510
So like my Macbook for example or
Zach's Macbook Air, there's only room for

00:01:53.510 --> 00:01:54.640
one hard drive in there.

42
00:01:54.640 --> 00:01:57.066

and backup to the same disk, but

00:02:00.202 --> 00:02:02.713
if your drive fails,
then you lose your backup, also.

45
00:02:02.713 --> 00:02:04.187
So that doesn't make any sense.

46
00:02:04.187 --> 00:02:07.710
>> You need to backup to some
kind of external system.

47
00:02:07.710 --> 00:02:09.760
And that's where things got really tricky,
for years,

48
00:02:09.760 --> 00:02:13.850
and years, having that external system
was kind of a hard thing to do.

49
00:02:13.850 --> 00:02:17.385
And some of the backup technologies
like backing up to tape that

50
00:02:17.385 --> 00:02:20.192
wasj ust a nightmare but
people still do it today.

51
00:02:20.192 --> 00:02:20.854
>> Goodness.

52
00:02:20.854 --> 00:02:23.484
>> But fortunately for

00:02:23.484 --> 00:02:27.263

54
00:02:27.263 --> 00:02:31.062
So this is a little USB hard drive, or
they make thunderbolt hard drives as well

55
00:02:31.062 --> 00:02:33.550
they're just more expensive and
I'm a tightwad.

56
00:02:33.550 --> 00:02:38.506
>> [LAUGH]
>> And so this is a USB 3.0 hard drive,

57
00:02:38.506 --> 00:02:42.154
they cost less than 100 bucks.

58
00:02:42.154 --> 00:02:46.698

probably $60 US, very very inexpensive.

59
00:02:46.698 --> 00:02:51.480
And you can plug it in your Mac and
it'll show up as an extra hard drive.

60
00:02:51.480 --> 00:02:57.110
And the system can then set up automated

61
00:02:57.110 --> 00:02:58.660
That's what Time Machine is doing.

62
00:02:58.660 --> 00:03:02.854
Time Machine is saying, here's this hard
drive, we're gonna use the store backups

63
00:03:02.854 --> 00:03:06.590
on and then it is routinely
reaching out and doing backups.

64
00:03:06.590 --> 00:03:09.400
It actually doing a backup once an hour.

65
00:03:09.400 --> 00:03:13.120
Once an hour, it's backing up
your data to this external disk.

66
00:03:13.120 --> 00:03:15.600
So when you have a failure,
worst case scenario,

67
00:03:15.600 --> 00:03:18.580
you might lose 59 minutes of your work.

68
00:03:18.580 --> 00:03:22.310
Because a backup definitely happened
within the last 60 minutes, right?

69
00:03:22.310 --> 00:03:25.350
So that's a great way to jump in there,
and you don't even have to think about it,

70
00:03:25.350 --> 00:03:27.250
once you turn it on, it just runs.

71
00:03:27.250 --> 00:03:30.320
You just have to remember to plug the disk
in, and then your backup occurs, and

72
00:03:30.320 --> 00:03:31.380
you're in business.

73
00:03:31.380 --> 00:03:33.600
But it's backing up once an hour.

74
00:03:33.600 --> 00:03:37.825
And then it's saving historical

episodes.description: In this episode, Don takes a look at what options are available when you need to run a Windows application on your Mac. He explains several possible solutions like macOS ported software and open source alternatives. He also explores using virtualization software like VMware's Fusion, to run a Windows virtual machine that will facilitate running Windows native apps.

Windows to be able to do that.

429
00:21:31.070 --> 00:21:34.120
You can fire it up,
access all the resources that you need.

430
00:21:34.120 --> 00:21:35.850
And now you can leverage that program.

431
00:21:35.850 --> 00:21:38.445
The problem is you're
booting into Windows.

432
00:21:38.445 --> 00:21:40.180
So you won't be able to run
any your Mac applications.

433
00:21:40.180 --> 00:21:41.210
But you can switch back and

434
00:21:41.210 --> 00:21:45.490
forth as you need, cuz now you
got them both on your hardware.

435
00:21:45.490 --> 00:21:47.120
And that's kinda files stuff.

436
00:21:47.120 --> 00:21:51.350
Like if I absolutely have to, I can still
have my Mac, but now I'm running Windows,

437
00:21:51.350 --> 00:21:54.150
MacOS is still sitting there though,
so I can flip back and forth.

438
00:21:54.150 --> 00:21:57.550
Now, quick thing I wanna mention here,
'cuz I haven't talked about it yet.

439
00:21:57.550 --> 00:21:59.750
When I said licensing,
it kinda set off a light in my head.

440
00:21:59.750 --> 00:22:00.250
>> There you go.

441
00:22:00.250 --> 00:22:02.400
>> I'm talking about Windows, right?

442
00:22:02.400 --> 00:22:05.080
If I run Windows in a virtual machine, or

443
00:22:05.080 --> 00:22:10.570
if I run Windows in BootCamp,
either way, I'm installing Windows.

444
00:22:10.570 --> 00:22:12.340
Microsoft has to get paid for that.

445
00:22:12.340 --> 00:22:13.640
That's a paid product.

446
00:22:13.640 --> 00:22:15.890
There's no free version of Windows
that you can go in and install.

447
00:22:15.890 --> 00:22:19.930
You can do demo versions, but there's
no free long-term one that you can run.

448
00:22:19.930 --> 00:22:22.090
You do have to buy a Windows license.

449
00:22:22.090 --> 00:22:25.760
If you choose virtualization, you're
paying for the virtualization software,

450
00:22:25.760 --> 00:22:27.970
which there are some free ones,
like VirtualBox, that are out there.

451
00:22:27.970 --> 00:22:29.990
But I'll tell you VMware Fusion,
and Parallels.

452
00:22:29.990 --> 00:22:31.000
Those two are the best.

453
00:22:31.000 --> 00:22:34.170
I like VMware Fusion,
it's worth the money.

454
00:22:34.170 --> 00:22:38.624
But then, a Microsoft Windows client
license, it can be upwards to $200.

455
00:22:38.624 --> 00:22:41.240
But you're paying for
that operating system.

456
00:22:41.240 --> 00:22:44.940
With MacOS, that operating
system comes with your hardware.

457
00:22:44.940 --> 00:22:46.990
But, that's not Microsoft, right?

458
00:22:46.990 --> 00:22:49.200
They need to get paid for their software,

459
00:22:49.200 --> 00:22:50.630
need is the right word there.
>> [LAUGH].

460
00:22:50.630 --> 00:22:51.714
>> But they want to get paid for

461
00:22:51.714 --> 00:22:53.530
their software.
>> Have to.

462
00:22:53.530 --> 00:22:55.190
>> So you do have to make sure that you

463
00:22:55.190 --> 00:22:57.950
got a legitimate license,
even if you're not booted up to it.

464
00:22:57.950 --> 00:23:00.150
If you install BootCamp and
then you never boot to it,

465
00:23:00.150 --> 00:23:03.990
it's still an installation of Windows, so
you got to make sure you've licensed that.

466
00:23:03.990 --> 00:23:05.870
Same thing with a virtual machine itself.

467
00:23:05.870 --> 00:23:08.470
These are all different
alternatives that give us

468
00:23:08.470 --> 00:23:12.570
access to the Windows software
that we might be dependent on.

469
00:23:12.570 --> 00:23:15.706
But today, so
many applications have moved to web-based,

470
00:23:15.706 --> 00:23:18.800
that this argument is
usually not even necessary.

471
00:23:18.800 --> 00:23:21.730
Yeah, its web-based, whatever,
I don't care what operating system I'm on.

472
00:23:21.730 --> 00:23:23.590
And that's a good place to be.

473
00:23:23.590 --> 00:23:27.310
But there are alternatives, Apple's given
us a number of different options here.

474
00:23:27.310 --> 00:23:29.820
So that we can still access
applications that we're dependent on.

475
00:23:29.820 --> 00:23:30.780
>> Well said Sir,

476
00:23:30.780 --> 00:23:33.970
running Windows applications,
great episode as usual, Don.

477
00:23:33.970 --> 00:23:38.890
And before we move on, last word, Sir.
>> You know, I mentioned BootCamp,

478
00:23:38.890 --> 00:23:39.940
but I didn't actually show it.

And the main reason is it

So if you're frustrated right now,

the BootCamp episode.

483

We’re gonna walk through

484
00:23:49.370 --> 00:23:52.710
Setting up from start to finish, and

It will be a lot of fun.

And they're there to help you go further,

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explores another option for working with Windows native applicationscalled Boot Camp. He explains when and why Boot Camp may be the correct solution for using Windows native apps and then demonstrates how to deploy a Boot Camp system.
episodes.title: Boot Camp
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:00.961
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your Don Pezet.

2
00:00:00.961 --> 00:00:01.830
>> Coming at you live from
San Franscico California.

3
00:00:01.830 --> 00:00:06.533
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.533 --> 00:00:08.648
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.648 --> 00:00:11.957
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.957 --> 00:00:13.050
>> Hello and thank you for
watching ITProTV.

7
00:00:13.050 --> 00:00:17.150
Empowering the world
through engaging learning.

8
00:00:17.150 --> 00:00:21.210
I'm your host Zach Memos as we continue
on, with Apple Certified Associate.

9
00:00:21.210 --> 00:00:25.460
The title of this episode,
get ready for it, Boot Camp.

10
00:00:25.460 --> 00:00:28.630
And our sergeant in arms
is gonna be Don Pezet.

11
00:00:28.630 --> 00:00:29.970
Don, thanks for joining us.

12
00:00:29.970 --> 00:00:31.410
>> Hey, thanks for having me, Zach.

13
00:00:31.410 --> 00:00:34.161
I was really tempted to try the drill
instructor voice for this episode.

14
00:00:34.161 --> 00:00:35.148
>> [LAUGH] I thought you might.

15
00:00:35.148 --> 00:00:37.366
>> I don't think I can keep it going for
30 minutes without losing my voice.

16
00:00:37.366 --> 00:00:39.575
So we'll have to settle for
my normal voice,

17
00:00:39.575 --> 00:00:41.740
as we jump into the world
of Apple Boot Camp.

18
00:00:41.740 --> 00:00:43.054
Which we'd eluded to in other episodes.

19
00:00:43.054 --> 00:00:44.960
>> We did.

20
00:00:44.960 --> 00:00:48.962
We talked about being able to run
the Microsoft Windows operating system,

21
00:00:48.962 --> 00:00:53.320
on top of our Apple hardware well Boot
Camp is the system that lets us do that.

22
00:00:53.320 --> 00:00:55.970
It is a little bit intimidating,
especially for

23
00:00:55.970 --> 00:00:57.420
users that have never done it before.

24
00:00:57.420 --> 00:01:00.647
But we´re gonna walk through that
process right here in this episode,

25
00:01:00.647 --> 00:01:02.203
see how it works, get a setup, and

26
00:01:02.203 --> 00:01:05.696
you´ll by the end of this episode that
it´s really not that bad, and it gives

27
00:01:05.696 --> 00:01:09.435
some extra functionality out of your
hardware that you wouldn't normally have.

28
00:01:09.435 --> 00:01:10.550
>> And Don this is right.

29
00:01:10.550 --> 00:01:13.322
You did touch on Boot Camp
in previous episodes, but

30
00:01:13.322 --> 00:01:16.537
what is the scenario where we
would actually need Boot Camp?

31
00:01:16.537 --> 00:01:20.043
>> All right so the main place that we
referred to was in the running Windows

32
00:01:20.043 --> 00:01:22.793
application episode
>> Where I talk about all these different

33
00:01:22.793 --> 00:01:25.342
ways to run Windows apps,
that were far easier, right?

34
00:01:25.342 --> 00:01:27.380
[LAUGH] That we'd normally want.

35
00:01:27.380 --> 00:01:32.440
For example, if I'm moving from
Windows environment to MacOS, and

36
00:01:32.440 --> 00:01:35.215
I used a program like sublime text.

37
00:01:35.215 --> 00:01:37.520
Well, they make a version of that,
from MacOS.

38
00:01:37.520 --> 00:01:39.300
So I just go on and
get a Mac version and that's that.

39
00:01:39.300 --> 00:01:42.940
Problem solved,
the episode's over, you're done.

40
00:01:42.940 --> 00:01:45.500
But, there's plenty of programs
where you can't do that.

41
00:01:45.500 --> 00:01:49.436
So, for example, NotePad ++ was
the example I gave in the other episode,

42
00:01:49.436 --> 00:01:52.893
that they have a Windows version,
they don't have a Mac version.

43
00:01:52.893 --> 00:01:56.290
So I could find some alternate
version of that software,

44
00:01:56.290 --> 00:01:58.425
some other competing text editor.

45
00:01:58.425 --> 00:02:01.003
But if I really love NotePad
++ I've gotta have it,

46
00:02:01.003 --> 00:02:02.850
then I have to run it on top of Windows.

47
00:02:02.850 --> 00:02:05.817
So, in that episode I showed you how
to do that in a virtual machine,

48
00:02:05.817 --> 00:02:08.350
I think I used VMWare Fusion
if I remember right.

49
00:02:08.350 --> 00:02:10.550
I fired up the VM in there,
and now you can run Notepad++.

50
00:02:10.550 --> 00:02:12.812
But that involves a virtual machine, and

51
00:02:12.812 --> 00:02:15.729
virtual machines can be
a little dicey in a few areas.

52
00:02:15.729 --> 00:02:20.348
One it's complex right, and most end users
don't understand virtual machines, or

53
00:02:20.348 --> 00:02:22.330
want to have to manage that.

54
00:02:22.330 --> 00:02:25.380
You can make it simple, but
it's a little more than one.

55
00:02:25.380 --> 00:02:30.810
The second thing is that, you might
have specific hardware requirements.

56
00:02:30.810 --> 00:02:35.181
I might have some Windows software, that
depends on a piece of hardware that only

57
00:02:35.181 --> 00:02:38.670
has Windows driver and
I can't run it inside a virtual machine.

58
00:02:38.670 --> 00:02:43.878
I've got to run it on the bare metal,
and that is where Boot Camp comes in,

59
00:02:43.878 --> 00:02:49.002
Boot Camp, lets just install
the Microsoft Windows operating system,

60
00:02:49.002 --> 00:02:51.102
right on our Apple hardware.

61
00:02:51.102 --> 00:02:55.439
Microsoft Windows operating system
runs on Intel and AMD processors,

62
00:02:55.439 --> 00:02:59.645
well, every Mac that's all these
days has an Intel processor in it.

63
00:02:59.645 --> 00:03:01.482
So it's standard PC hardware.

64
00:03:01.482 --> 00:03:05.475
All right, Apple made a lot of it, but
the technology itself comes from Intel and

65
00:03:05.475 --> 00:03:06.709
Windows supports it, so

66
00:03:06.709 --> 00:03:10.196
there's really no reason why we
can't just install Windows on here.

67
00:03:10.196 --> 00:03:12.070
Well, there's a little reason.

68
00:03:12.070 --> 00:03:16.192
The bios that manages your entire Mac,
is built by Apple and

69
00:03:16.192 --> 00:03:21.646
is closed-source to Apple, and so
they control what can run on the hardware.

70
00:03:21.646 --> 00:03:25.495
But they're confident enough in their own
operating system, they say, hey, look,

71
00:03:25.495 --> 00:03:28.890
if you need to run Windows,
we'll let you, we'll help you out.

72
00:03:28.890 --> 00:03:32.311
And what Boot Camp let's us do,
is kind of divide our computer in half,

73
00:03:32.311 --> 00:03:33.803
give it split personalities.

74
00:03:33.803 --> 00:03:38.140
So that it's got one personality of MacOS,
and another personality of Windows.

75
00:03:38.140 --> 00:03:42.974
And when we push the power button, we then
get to pick, do I wanna boot to Windows,

76
00:03:42.974 --> 00:03:44.602
or do I wanna boot to MacOS?

77
00:03:44.602 --> 00:03:49.580
And if I boot to MacOS, I'm in regular
MacOS, just like normal, I'm using my Mac.

78
00:03:49.580 --> 00:03:53.909
If I boot to Windows though, Windows fires
up, and now I've got my applications, and

79
00:03:53.909 --> 00:03:57.069
we can get up and running with
whatever it is that we need there.

80
00:03:57.069 --> 00:04:00.960
But it's not running
them at the same time.

81
00:04:00.960 --> 00:04:05.750
When I showed virtualization like VMWare
Fusion, that let me run, Windows and

82
00:04:05.750 --> 00:04:08.894
Mac OS at the same time, and
even mix them together so

83
00:04:08.894 --> 00:04:11.196
the apps from one show up in the other.

84
00:04:11.196 --> 00:04:14.101
That's really cool stuff and
it's super convenient.

85
00:04:14.101 --> 00:04:15.944
You get the best of both worlds.

86
00:04:15.944 --> 00:04:17.784
With Boot Camp, you don't.

87
00:04:17.784 --> 00:04:20.730
You boot-up and you boot to one world,
or you boot to the other.

88
00:04:20.730 --> 00:04:22.335
You can't be in both at the same time.

89
00:04:22.335 --> 00:04:26.010
So, if you're in the Windows world,
you're just seeing Windows.

90
00:04:26.010 --> 00:04:29.330
And if you're go into the MacOS
world you're just seeing MacOS, and

91
00:04:29.330 --> 00:04:30.830
that the apps that are associated with it.

92
00:04:30.830 --> 00:04:32.454
So, keep that in mind as you try and

93
00:04:32.454 --> 00:04:34.978
figure out which of these
solutions is right for you.

94
00:04:34.978 --> 00:04:40.140
Should I use of VM, should I use Boot
Camp, should I find some other software?

95
00:04:41.200 --> 00:04:42.890
The sure answer is yes, right?

96
00:04:42.890 --> 00:04:44.358
All of those work, but

97
00:04:44.358 --> 00:04:48.933
find the one that does matches up to
your scenario to pick the you need.

98
00:04:48.933 --> 00:04:49.793
>> Split personality.

99
00:04:49.793 --> 00:04:51.862
Does Boot Camp work on every Mac?

100
00:04:51.862 --> 00:04:52.770
You know it does.

101
00:04:52.770 --> 00:04:56.940
At least, as of this episode being filmed,
the main requirements for Boot Camp.

102
00:04:56.940 --> 00:05:01.390
You have to have an Intel processor,
which all of the Macs do, not iPads or

103
00:05:01.390 --> 00:05:02.010
iPhones, right?

104
00:05:02.010 --> 00:05:03.430
They use ARM processors.

105
00:05:03.430 --> 00:05:05.180
Not ARMs, Cortex processors.

106
00:05:05.180 --> 00:05:08.420
They're different, and
they're not the same.

107
00:05:08.420 --> 00:05:09.770
So, that's not gonna work.

108
00:05:09.770 --> 00:05:11.617
But, as far as Macs go.

109
00:05:11.617 --> 00:05:16.049
All the MacBooks, the iMacs,
Mac Minis, Mac Pros MacBook Airs,

110
00:05:16.049 --> 00:05:18.120
all of them support Boot Camp.

111
00:05:18.120 --> 00:05:21.644
The main thing that you have to
watch out for is disk space.

112
00:05:21.644 --> 00:05:23.574
You do need a bit of disk space,

113
00:05:23.574 --> 00:05:29.093
Microsoft's requirement is 40 gigs of hard
drive space, and at least 2 gigs of RAM.

114
00:05:29.093 --> 00:05:32.080
Well, pretty much every
Mac has 2 gigs of RAM.

115
00:05:32.080 --> 00:05:34.990
You can actually do 1 gig,
even though they tell you 2 gigs.

116
00:05:34.990 --> 00:05:39.374
2 GB of RAM is the requirement, 1 GB is
enough to get it going, but it'll be slow.

117
00:05:39.374 --> 00:05:40.430
You really want two or more.

118
00:05:40.430 --> 00:05:42.757
Pretty much every Mac has that these days.

119
00:05:42.757 --> 00:05:47.000
So, the hard drive space,
we need 40 gigs of hard drive space.

120
00:05:47.000 --> 00:05:49.840
Well, every Mac comes with a hard
drive bigger than 40 gigs.

121
00:05:49.840 --> 00:05:54.750
In fact, I think if you do
the cheapest MacBook Air,

122
00:05:54.750 --> 00:05:56.260
I think you can get a 128 gig drive.

123
00:05:56.260 --> 00:05:57.707
That would be the smallest, right?

124
00:05:57.707 --> 00:06:00.368
So you might look at that and say,
I definitely got tons of space.

125
00:06:00.368 --> 00:06:04.415
Well, we need 40 gigs of free hard
drive space, it needs to be empty.

126
00:06:04.415 --> 00:06:07.989
Because what's gonna happen is the hard
drive has to get divided, right?

127
00:06:07.989 --> 00:06:12.964
MAC OS uses either the MAC OS
extended journal file system, or

128
00:06:12.964 --> 00:06:15.463
APFS, the Apple file system.

129
00:06:15.463 --> 00:06:17.345
Windows can't read those.

130
00:06:17.345 --> 00:06:20.254
Well that's not entirely true,
it can read it but it can't write to it.

131
00:06:20.254 --> 00:06:23.242
But Windows can't use that file system.

132
00:06:23.242 --> 00:06:26.790
Windows, is the NTFS file system.

133
00:06:26.790 --> 00:06:29.823
Apple can read the NTFS file system,
but it can't write to it.

134
00:06:29.823 --> 00:06:34.971
So they can't write to each other's file
system, so they can't share a file system.

135
00:06:34.971 --> 00:06:38.174
That means I'm gonna have to divide
my hard drive up into volumes.

136
00:06:38.174 --> 00:06:40.820
One volume for Windows,
one volume for Mac OS.

137
00:06:40.820 --> 00:06:43.086
And when they boot,
they boot to their own volume.

138
00:06:43.086 --> 00:06:46.130
So I need 40 gigs of free space.

139
00:06:46.130 --> 00:06:47.307
To be able to set aside for Windows.

140
00:06:47.307 --> 00:06:50.932
Now, I'll tell you,
40 gigs is not a lot of space.

141
00:06:50.932 --> 00:06:53.820
You're usually going to want 100 gigs or
more, because,

142
00:06:53.820 --> 00:06:55.830
you need the operating system installed.

143
00:06:55.830 --> 00:06:58.907
But then all of the other applications and
documents that you're gonna install, too.

144
00:06:58.907 --> 00:07:01.080
So disk space is your big limiting factor.

145
00:07:01.080 --> 00:07:03.668
Otherwise the hardware on
pretty much every modern

146
00:07:03.668 --> 00:07:05.905
Mac supports running Bootcamp if you want.

147
00:07:05.905 --> 00:07:08.961
Now that's gonna change in the future.

148
00:07:08.961 --> 00:07:12.167
But for right now, every Mac made
in the last, probably the last,

149
00:07:12.167 --> 00:07:14.815
ten years can run Boot Camp,
and get this up and going.

150
00:07:14.815 --> 00:07:18.251
>> So can we see a Boot Camp
installation right here on the show?

151
00:07:18.251 --> 00:07:19.378
>> Absolutely, yeah.

152
00:07:19.378 --> 00:07:22.574
It's a little bit weird that the way I
normally share my video doesn't quite work

153
00:07:22.574 --> 00:07:24.041
when we start booting into Windows.

154
00:07:24.041 --> 00:07:26.154
So I have to have things up
a little differently but,

155
00:07:26.154 --> 00:07:29.300
I've got a Mac Mini here on my desk,
what we're looking at right here.

156
00:07:29.300 --> 00:07:32.480
It's pretty much just a clean
install of MacOS High Sierra.

157
00:07:32.480 --> 00:07:35.397
I haven't really done anything
