episodes.description: In this episode, Don explores another option for working with Windows native applicationscalled Boot Camp. He explains when and why Boot Camp may be the correct solution for using Windows native apps and then demonstrates how to deploy a Boot Camp system.
episodes.title: Boot Camp Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:03.482
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.482 --> 00:00:05.989
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.989 --> 00:00:08.386
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.386 --> 00:00:11.989
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.989 --> 00:00:13.136
>> Hello, and thank you for

6
00:00:13.136 --> 00:00:16.530
watching ITProTV, empowering
the world through engaging learning.

7
00:00:16.530 --> 00:00:20.040
I'm your host, Zach Memos, for this
episode of Apple Certified Associates.

8
00:00:20.040 --> 00:00:22.240
This is bootcamp, part two.

9
00:00:22.240 --> 00:00:24.600
And our drill sergeant,
once again, is Don Pezet.

10
00:00:24.600 --> 00:00:26.810
Don, great to see you again,
sir, let's move on.

11
00:00:26.810 --> 00:00:27.480
>> Great to be back.

12
00:00:27.480 --> 00:00:29.580
Ready to drop and give me 20 or-
>> Yes, I will.

13
00:00:29.580 --> 00:00:31.464
>> [CROSSTALK] You should drop and
give me, no-

14
00:00:31.464 --> 00:00:32.140
>> [LAUGH]

15
00:00:32.140 --> 00:00:32.710
>> Anyhow,

16
00:00:32.710 --> 00:00:33.830
we're kicking back into boot camp.

17
00:00:33.830 --> 00:00:37.250
And if you watched part one, you know
we left off where we're all prepared.

18
00:00:37.250 --> 00:00:40.150
I mean, our USB key's built up,
our drive is divided.

19
00:00:40.150 --> 00:00:42.570
We are ready to get Windows installed.

20
00:00:42.570 --> 00:00:44.440
So that's gonna happen
right here in this episode.

21
00:00:44.440 --> 00:00:48.390
We're gonna take the plunge and make
actual, significant change to our Mac,

22
00:00:48.390 --> 00:00:50.360
to get both operating systems up and
going so that's-

23
00:00:50.360 --> 00:00:51.460
>> See that's boot camp.

24
00:00:51.460 --> 00:00:53.130
>> The adventure we've got
lined up in this episode.

25
00:00:53.130 --> 00:00:57.040
All right, so without further ado, let's
go ahead and just dive right back in.

26
00:00:57.040 --> 00:01:00.440
And if we take a look at my system,
you'll see where I left it, right,

27
00:01:00.440 --> 00:01:04.530
where we had made that decision of
how we were gonna divide the disk.

28
00:01:04.530 --> 00:01:08.960
And now we're left with that
final moment of hesitation, like

29
00:01:08.960 --> 00:01:10.180
>> Wait, before you push the button,

30
00:01:10.180 --> 00:01:11.020
I have a question for you.

31
00:01:11.020 --> 00:01:14.459
>> Okay.
>> So how much or how little room for

32
00:01:14.459 --> 00:01:17.879
the macOS can you leave, I mean-
>> So

33
00:01:17.879 --> 00:01:21.790
I did kinda glanced over that
really briefly in the last episode.

34
00:01:21.790 --> 00:01:24.382
I said you can shrink the drive
as much as you want, but

35
00:01:24.382 --> 00:01:26.190
you've gotta leave room for macOS.

36
00:01:26.190 --> 00:01:28.470
Well, if you notice, or maybe not.

37
00:01:28.470 --> 00:01:30.810
Let me see if I jam it
all the way across here.

38
00:01:30.810 --> 00:01:35.030
It will let you go as small as you can to
contain the data that's already in there.

39
00:01:35.030 --> 00:01:35.610
>> Right.

40
00:01:35.610 --> 00:01:39.610
>> Plus 8 gigs of free space,
right, which is not a lot, so.

41
00:01:39.610 --> 00:01:40.790
>> That's where it stops.

42
00:01:40.790 --> 00:01:43.080
>> It's whatever space
you're already consuming.

43
00:01:43.080 --> 00:01:47.240
So I must be consuming 35 gigs of space,
and then it sticks 8 on there.

44
00:01:47.240 --> 00:01:50.410
So if you were only consuming,
like on a brand new, fresh install,

45
00:01:50.410 --> 00:01:52.770
maybe you're only
consuming 15 gigs of space,

46
00:01:52.770 --> 00:01:55.240
then this number would be
able to come down to 23 gigs.

47
00:01:55.240 --> 00:01:58.050
>> Okay.
>> So that's how it kinda works out.

48
00:01:58.050 --> 00:02:00.520
That's too small,
8 gigs of space is not a lot.

49
00:02:00.520 --> 00:02:04.560
If you install, I don't know,
Adobe Premier or something like that,

50
00:02:04.560 --> 00:02:06.590
the application alone will
eat up a lot of that space.

51
00:02:06.590 --> 00:02:08.270
So you don't wanna go too small.

52
00:02:08.270 --> 00:02:10.990
But like I said in the last episode,
you wanna make sure you try and

53
00:02:10.990 --> 00:02:13.840
leave an adequate amount of space for
what you're trying to do.

54
00:02:13.840 --> 00:02:15.965
All right, so I've got mine set,
I'm ready to take the plunge.

55
00:02:15.965 --> 00:02:17.560
I'm gonna click Install.

56
00:02:17.560 --> 00:02:19.100
And now comes our moment of truth, right?

57
00:02:19.100 --> 00:02:21.890
So right down here,
you can see Status: Partitioning disk.

58
00:02:21.890 --> 00:02:25.680
It's dividing that disk up,
it's shrinking the macOS partition.

59
00:02:25.680 --> 00:02:26.960
And once it's shrunk,

60
00:02:26.960 --> 00:02:30.740
then it's adding in the new Windows
partition to the end of it.

61
00:02:30.740 --> 00:02:35.120
And once that's done, now it's got
a place where it can install Windows.

62
00:02:35.120 --> 00:02:37.177
Now quick word of warning,

63
00:02:37.177 --> 00:02:42.103
I made my partitions two different sizes,
185 and 64 gigs.

64
00:02:42.103 --> 00:02:46.930
If you hit Divide Equally,
the two partitions look the same.

65
00:02:46.930 --> 00:02:50.820
And when you boot into Windows,
it does this super annoying thing

66
00:02:50.820 --> 00:02:54.030
where it asks you to format a drive and
it doesn't really tell you which is which.

67
00:02:54.030 --> 00:02:58.350
And if they're the same size,
how do you know which is which?

68
00:02:58.350 --> 00:03:02.390
There's a real moment of just-
>> Very cringe worthy.

69
00:03:02.390 --> 00:03:04.900
>> Fear,
am I about to pick the wrong partition?

70
00:03:04.900 --> 00:03:06.130
And it's certainly possible.

71
00:03:06.130 --> 00:03:08.390
So I'll show you that when
we get to the Windows side.

72
00:03:08.390 --> 00:03:11.890
But a little trick that I like to use is,
even when I hit Divide Equally,

73
00:03:11.890 --> 00:03:14.810
I'll make one partition at least
one gig bigger than the other.

74
00:03:14.810 --> 00:03:17.820
And that way I now exactly which
one is the macOS partition and

75
00:03:17.820 --> 00:03:19.430
which one is the Windows partition.

76
00:03:19.430 --> 00:03:21.389
In my case,
I know the Windows one is 64 gig.

77
00:03:21.389 --> 00:03:23.740
So I'll be able to look and
find that easy enough.

78
00:03:23.740 --> 00:03:25.560
But that's something I
bumped into in real life.

79
00:03:25.560 --> 00:03:29.500
You guys might bump into as well when
you use that Divide Equally button.

80
00:03:29.500 --> 00:03:30.240
>> Good advice.

81
00:03:30.240 --> 00:03:33.210
>> Now it is taking a little bit
longer to do my partitioning,

82
00:03:34.770 --> 00:03:37.270
two reasons why that might happen.

83
00:03:37.270 --> 00:03:39.300
One, if your disk has been heavily used,

84
00:03:39.300 --> 00:03:40.775
you might have files
scattered about on it.

85
00:03:40.775 --> 00:03:43.430
It's having to rearrange
a bit to accommodate that.

86
00:03:43.430 --> 00:03:47.250
Two, if you have FileVault
encryption turned on.

87
00:03:47.250 --> 00:03:50.600
Resizing an encrypted disk is
actually a little bit difficult.

88
00:03:50.600 --> 00:03:54.250
Because the empty space is encrypted,
so it looks like it's full space.

89
00:03:54.250 --> 00:03:56.050
So it's gotta kinda
manipulate around that.

90
00:03:56.050 --> 00:03:59.180
So in my case,
that's likely what's going on here.

91
00:03:59.180 --> 00:04:00.440
>> Cuz you have FileVault?

92
00:04:00.440 --> 00:04:02.650
>> Yeah, yep, and so
it can take a little bit longer.

93
00:04:02.650 --> 00:04:05.150
If you don't have FileVault,
this process normally is pretty fast.

94
00:04:05.150 --> 00:04:06.540
There we go, so it's done.

95
00:04:06.540 --> 00:04:09.900
And I'm gonna punch in my
administrative password here.

96
00:04:09.900 --> 00:04:12.680
And now my system reboots, okay.

97
00:04:12.680 --> 00:04:14.710
Now the system's rebooting.

98
00:04:14.710 --> 00:04:16.867
And when it goes to boot back up,

99
00:04:16.867 --> 00:04:22.340
your Mac has already been set
to boot from the USB key, right?

100
00:04:22.340 --> 00:04:25.720
If something goes wrong and you fail to
boot, like maybe the system doesn't come

101
00:04:25.720 --> 00:04:27.141
back up-
>> And there it is.

102
00:04:27.141 --> 00:04:30.810
>> Then you can hit the power button
while holding the Option key, and

103
00:04:30.810 --> 00:04:33.500
you'll see the USB key, and
you can pick and you can boot from it.

104
00:04:33.500 --> 00:04:35.740
In my case though, I didn't need to
hit the power while I was doing it.

105
00:04:35.740 --> 00:04:36.870
So it's rebooting.

106
00:04:36.870 --> 00:04:41.080
And like Zach pointed out, I'm not seeing
an Apple with a little bar going across.

107
00:04:41.080 --> 00:04:43.330
I'm seeing the Microsoft Windows logo.

108
00:04:43.330 --> 00:04:44.434
I'm doing Windows 10.

109
00:04:44.434 --> 00:04:46.540
If you're doing Windows 7,
the logo is a little bit different.

110
00:04:46.540 --> 00:04:48.930
But the process is the same, right?

111
00:04:48.930 --> 00:04:55.300
So it's gonna boot, and it's gonna
go into the Microsoft installer.

112
00:04:55.300 --> 00:04:57.820
And the Microsoft installer,
for the most part,

113
00:04:57.820 --> 00:04:59.470
doesn't have to ask us too many questions.

114
00:04:59.470 --> 00:05:02.781
Because Apple has already filled in
a lot of the blanks for us, all right?

115
00:05:02.781 --> 00:05:04.140
But it will ask a few things.

116
00:05:04.140 --> 00:05:07.490
We're gonna see a licensing screen
that we've got to adhere to.

117
00:05:07.490 --> 00:05:10.680
But when it boots up,
if you've ever installed Windows before,

118
00:05:10.680 --> 00:05:13.510
you normally get a bunch of questions
here where it's asking things like,

119
00:05:13.510 --> 00:05:15.740
which disk do you want it to install.

120
00:05:15.740 --> 00:05:18.050
Assuming that it's got all
the information it needs,

121
00:05:18.050 --> 00:05:19.810
a lot of that will get answered for us.

122
00:05:19.810 --> 00:05:23.620
All right, my first screen here
is asking about my language.

123
00:05:23.620 --> 00:05:26.070
Let me zoom in on that a bit.

124
00:05:26.070 --> 00:05:28.140
All right, so
it's just asking me to pick the language.

125
00:05:28.140 --> 00:05:30.710
And this is really talking about
the language that your keyboard uses,

126
00:05:30.710 --> 00:05:32.670
as well as what the system
is going to use.

127
00:05:32.670 --> 00:05:37.320
So it's defaulting to English for me,
which is fine, so I'll stick with that.

128
00:05:37.320 --> 00:05:39.960
And now it’s going to ask for
a product key.

129
00:05:39.960 --> 00:05:44.260
Remember I said that if we want to install
Windows, we've got to have a product key.

130
00:05:44.260 --> 00:05:45.670
We've gotta type it in.

131
00:05:45.670 --> 00:05:49.400
If you don’t have one, you can choose
that option down at the bottom.

132
00:05:49.400 --> 00:05:51.570
See how it says,
I don’t have a product key?

133
00:05:51.570 --> 00:05:55.770
And if you choose that option,
it will actually let you do the install.

134
00:05:55.770 --> 00:05:57.492
But you're gonna install as an evaluation.

135
00:05:57.492 --> 00:05:58.440
And the evaluation,

136
00:05:58.440 --> 00:06:03.520
depending on how you got your copy of
Windows, it's usually 60 days, two months.

137
00:06:03.520 --> 00:06:07.592
And so you can run with the eval copy,
and it will be all right like that.

138
00:06:07.592 --> 00:06:12.440
If you're just doing this to test and
try, then you can go that route.

139
00:06:12.440 --> 00:06:13.920
If you actually have bought it,

140
00:06:13.920 --> 00:06:16.250
then you'll punch in your
product key right there.

141
00:06:16.250 --> 00:06:17.700
Since I didn't put in a product key,

142
00:06:17.700 --> 00:06:20.130
on the next screen it's gonna ask
me which edition I'm installing.

143
00:06:20.130 --> 00:06:21.465
If I had put in a product key,

144
00:06:21.465 --> 00:06:24.470
it would know whether I had
bought Home edition or Pro.

145
00:06:24.470 --> 00:06:25.260
I'll do Pro.

146
00:06:26.320 --> 00:06:28.680
There's differences there depending
on what you're trying do.

147
00:06:28.680 --> 00:06:30.810
One's cheaper, Home is cheaper.

148
00:06:30.810 --> 00:06:33.480
But we'll do Pro, and
we'll advance forward.

149
00:06:33.480 --> 00:06:38.120
On the next screen, it's gonna start
doing the end user license agreement.

150
00:06:38.120 --> 00:06:41.460
The fun stuff the attorneys all love,
because it keeps them employed.

151
00:06:41.460 --> 00:06:46.238
And it's basically just asking me whether
or not I am allowed to do what I'm doing,

152
00:06:46.238 --> 00:06:49.365
and whether Microsoft can sue me or
if I can sue them.

153
00:06:49.365 --> 00:06:52.740
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, now here's the screen I was

154
00:06:52.740 --> 00:06:56.980
warning you about, where you could
potentially choose the wrong disk.

155
00:06:56.980 --> 00:06:58.480
When you look at your disk,

156
00:06:58.480 --> 00:07:02.320
it's showing your hard drive
divided up into partitions.

157
00:07:02.320 --> 00:07:05.470
And I can see Partition 2 here,
that's my Apple partition.

158
00:07:05.470 --> 00:07:06.940
And then this next one, Partition 3, and

159
00:07:06.940 --> 00:07:09.120
see how they've labeled it BOOTCAMP,
right?

160
00:07:09.120 --> 00:07:11.950
That's the big warning thing for
you, use this for BOOTCAMP.

161
00:07:11.950 --> 00:07:13.820
So if there's two of them
that are the same size,

162
00:07:13.820 --> 00:07:17.570
that's the indicator that can kinda
help us figure out which one is which.

163
00:07:17.570 --> 00:07:20.250
If it's not labeled though,
sometimes it's not labeled, and

164
00:07:20.250 --> 00:07:23.950
if it's not, having a slightly different
size is a great way to tell them apart.

165
00:07:23.950 --> 00:07:26.226
I made it's 64 gigs, so
I can see there's a difference thing.

166
00:07:26.226 --> 00:07:27.830
Notice how the numbers don't quite match.

167
00:07:27.830 --> 00:07:30.486
I chose 64 gig, but it's actually 60.4.

168
00:07:30.486 --> 00:07:35.322
And the other one was 185,
I think, and now it's 172.

169
00:07:35.322 --> 00:07:39.490
That's because Windows measures disks
a little differently than macOS does.

170
00:07:39.490 --> 00:07:41.400
That's the old Unix style measurement.

171
00:07:41.400 --> 00:07:42.720
But basically I'm gonna choose this one.

172
00:07:42.720 --> 00:07:45.670
Now, here is a sticking point
that a lot of people bump into.

173
00:07:45.670 --> 00:07:48.790
When I choose that BOOTCAMP partition,
look at the warning.

174
00:07:48.790 --> 00:07:53.132
Windows can't be installed on Drive 0,
Partition 3.

175
00:07:53.132 --> 00:07:56.130
Well, it's labeled BOOTCAMP,
why can't I install?

176
00:07:56.130 --> 00:07:58.260
And if I click some other partitions,
I get the same thing, right?

177
00:07:58.260 --> 00:08:00.718
So I can't install in any of these,
it won't let me move forward.

178
00:08:00.718 --> 00:08:04.322
Well the reason is,
Apple didn't license the NT file system,

179
00:08:04.322 --> 00:08:08.360
the file system that Windows uses,
they didn't license it.

180
00:08:08.360 --> 00:08:10.930
So they couldn't format
the disk ahead of time,

181
00:08:10.930 --> 00:08:13.260
it's formatted with the wrong file system.

182
00:08:13.260 --> 00:08:16.630
And so Windows is saying,
I can't install on that, right?

183
00:08:16.630 --> 00:08:19.580
So all you have to do is choose
that boot camp partition and

184
00:08:19.580 --> 00:08:24.250
hit format, and when you choose format,
Windows will format it for you.

185
00:08:24.250 --> 00:08:28.320
I'll just say OK to that, and
it's gonna format it and now,

186
00:08:28.320 --> 00:08:29.380
see how the warning went away?

187
00:08:29.380 --> 00:08:29.920
>> Ran away.

188
00:08:29.920 --> 00:08:32.820
>> And I can install, but,
the label went away too and

189
00:08:32.820 --> 00:08:34.320
here's where we could
potentially mix up again.

190
00:08:34.320 --> 00:08:36.460
If I had two disks that
were the same size,

191
00:08:36.460 --> 00:08:39.470
I could lose track of which one was
boot camp and which one wasn't.

192
00:08:39.470 --> 00:08:44.000
All right, so I'm gonna choose that one,
now I can hit my next button, and

193
00:08:44.000 --> 00:08:46.320
now it's ready to do the install.

194
00:08:46.320 --> 00:08:51.420
Now on a SSD based system, installing
Windows 7 takes about 20 minutes,

195
00:08:51.420 --> 00:08:52.230
all right?

196
00:08:52.230 --> 00:08:54.070
It'll say some various
times here in a minute,

197
00:08:54.070 --> 00:08:57.090
they're all lies,
it usually takes about 20 minutes.

198
00:08:58.160 --> 00:09:02.110
On a slower system it could take as long
as an hour, but in one way or another,

199
00:09:02.110 --> 00:09:04.055
you're gonna be twiddling
your thumbs here for a bit.

200
00:09:04.055 --> 00:09:06.610
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's gotta copy all of the files

201
00:09:06.610 --> 00:09:10.440
from the USB key over to that
new partition on the hard drive.

202
00:09:10.440 --> 00:09:14.250
And once that's done, it's gotta copy
over the drivers, it's gotta boot up

203
00:09:14.250 --> 00:09:18.228
one time to load the drivers and it's
gotta reboot again to start the install.

204
00:09:18.228 --> 00:09:21.150
So that's gotta reboot
a couple of times and so

205
00:09:21.150 --> 00:09:26.810
what we get to do as IT administrators,
or Apple Certified Associates, is wait.

206
00:09:26.810 --> 00:09:29.550
And this is how I've spent
a good bit of my career is

207
00:09:29.550 --> 00:09:32.320
watching screens like
these slowly tick along.

208
00:09:32.320 --> 00:09:35.310
Fortunately in TV land,
we can do that in fast forward.

209
00:09:35.310 --> 00:09:38.121
So we're gonna warp ahead a little bit,
we'll reach out to Mr.

210
00:09:38.121 --> 00:09:39.640
Scotty here and see what he can do.

211
00:09:39.640 --> 00:09:43.074
And as soon as this is done,
we'll be ready to see Windows boot

212
00:09:43.074 --> 00:09:45.995
the first time and
start to interact with boot camp.

213
00:09:45.995 --> 00:09:51.049
[MUSIC]

214
00:09:51.049 --> 00:09:54.460
All right ladies and gentlemen, looks like
we are finally at our little spot here.

215
00:09:54.460 --> 00:09:57.580
If you watched in fast forward,
basically, it just kinda sat there and

216
00:09:57.580 --> 00:09:58.915
ticked off a little time.

217
00:09:58.915 --> 00:10:00.570
>> [LAUGH]
>> Exhausting work.

218
00:10:00.570 --> 00:10:04.110
And then it rebooted,
they rebooted and did some more stuff.

219
00:10:04.110 --> 00:10:07.480
And then now it dropped me off
at what's called the quickstart.

220
00:10:07.480 --> 00:10:10.390
Quickstart just asks a handful of
questions to make sure the computer is

221
00:10:10.390 --> 00:10:11.280
setup right.

222
00:10:11.280 --> 00:10:13.595
The first question is,
let's pick your region, right?

223
00:10:13.595 --> 00:10:16.065
>> So it's recognized that I'm
